description: Borrowed from French récalcitrant, from Latin recalcitrāns, recalcitrantis, present participle of recalcitrō, recalcitrāre (“be disobedient, kick back [as a horse]”), from calx (“heel”), 1820s.

adjectives.description: recalcitrant (comparative more recalcitrant, superlative most recalcitrant)

entries.meaning: Marked by a stubborn unwillingness to obey authority.
examples: His nimble fancy was recalcitrant to mental discipline.

entries.meaning: Difficult to deal with or to operate.
examples: The more labile organic constituents of complex dissolved and particulate organic matter are commonly hydrolyzed and metabolized more rapidly than more recalcitrant organic compounds that are less accessible enzymatically.

entries.meaning: (botany, of seed, pollen, spores) Not viable for an extended period; damaged by drying or freezing.
